title: Wednesday, 8th February, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:01am

Our daily chat, where we have a habit of sharing the writing from various City research analysts

PM11:02am

I guess it falls to us Bryce -- to launch a defence of the humble sell-side research bod

11:01 am
BE11:02am

Does it? Why?

BE11:02am

Or rather, apropos of what?

PM11:02am

Backreading here https://www.ft.com...-930f-061b01e23655

11:02 am
BE11:02am

Oh.

PM11:02am

And here: https://www.ft.com...-ba01-119a44939bb6

BE11:02am

Ah,

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Basically the FT's sacking them all

BE11:02am

Hm.

PM11:03am

Can you imagine how much typing we'd have to do here if that came to pass

11:03 am
BE11:03am

Well, indeed.

PM11:04am

Research departments have been "under pressure" "set for huge culls" etc ever since I began this game

PM11:04am

Some analysts are crap, right?

11:04 am
PM11:04am

And some are brilliant

BE11:04am

It's a fact that sellside doesn't really make sense, as an economic model. And it's true, undeniably, that some analysts are crap.

BE11:05am

Or rather, there's maintenance research and there's other research.

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Yeah

BE11:05am

This isn't captured by simple analysis of which buy recommendation went up and which sell went down. That's simplistic to the point of offensive.

BE11:06am

I mean, one of the best bits of research I read last year was Paul Cuddon of Numis on GW Pharma.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

It was wrong, in terms of the recommendation. Spectacularly so, in fact. About 100% wrong.

PM11:07am

hehehe

PM11:07am

But still a brilliant read

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Yes, the work that went into it -- the digging into the market for epilepsy drugs and the deep understanding of potential size and trajectory of sector pipelines -- well, if no fund manager finds that useful, then that's a shocking indictment of fund managers.

PM11:08am

Thumbs up

BE11:08am

Should Numis be giving it away for free? Probably not, but that's the model right now.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

And I can list, off the top of my head, two dozen analysts doing top-grade work that informs the consensus in a way that takes them well outside the realm of "stock tips".

PM11:10am

(Welcome back alewis2005)

BE11:11am

The UBS media team. James Tracey and Stephen Swanton of Redburn. Nearly everyone at Bernstein. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. The housing guys at Shore. Prew and Sandy at Jefferies. Don't trade on it, just damn read it. Learn something.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Anyway.

PM11:11am

Yeah, so that's our position

PM11:11am

Generally, we love the sell-side

11:11 am
PM11:12am

And wish them well under Mifid II

BE11:12am

I've not even gotten onto desk notes, the semi-secret world of sellside. But Levine was exceptionally good on that theme a few days ago. Read him instead.

BE11:13am

Link: https://www.bloomb...s-and-poker-robots

11:13 am
BE11:13am

(@littleclenches: Thumbs up yes, and him. Too many to mention, in fact.)

undefined
PM11:13am

So the markets flat

11:13 am
PM11:14am

Omg smile

BE11:14am

Yeah, collapsed into the close yesterday as sterling rallied .....

PM11:14am

GBK going nowhere in particular this morning

11:14 am
PM11:14am

We're going to have to fall back on sellside

BE11:15am

....... That's no bad thing. Though there isn't a tremendous amount around today.

BE11:15am

There's Sophos, I guess.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

A company whose numbers challenge most people's understanding, in part because it made up its own metric for sales.

PM11:16am

That's novel

BE11:17am

Will Wallis of Numis -- another of those damn sellside analysts -- spent a long time explaining it to me.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Seems it's fine. Ish. Anyway.

BE11:18am

Today they've bought Invincea

BE11:19am

Which is a quite hype-y virus and malware thing

11:18 am
PM11:19am

Yeah, just looking at that

PM11:19am

Headquartered in Fairfax, Virginia, with approximately 100 employees, Invincea has been consistently ranked as among the best performing machine learning, signatureless next-generation endpoint technologies in third-party testing, rated highly both for high detection and low false-positive rates. Invincea has a strong presence in the US, particularly in the government, healthcare and financial services sectors. The Invincea endpoint security portfolio prevents, detects and remediates zero-day and sophisticated attacks, and combines neural-network based machine learning and behavioral monitoring to enhance detection through artificial intelligence and stop evasive malware before damage occurs.

BE11:19am

Yup. Involving lots of buzzwords about machine learning and suchlike.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

If you're really interested, here's the research paper from the head wonks explaining it all: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1508.03096v2.pdf

PM11:20am

Ah, hell, i clicked

BE11:20am

It's $100 million plus a $20 million earn-out ......

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Which is -- uh -- punchy.

PM11:20am

∗∗∗
L(y ,yˆ) = − ∑ yˆj logyj +(1−yˆj)log(1−yj)

BE11:21am

Yes, that. And that's $120m gor $13.4m of billings and $9.8m of revenues

11:21 am
BE11:21am

So we're looking at the benefit of dropping this thing into Sophos's suite.

BE11:22am

Which might work -- it's worked before -- though scanning Glassdoor does rather give the impression that Invincea is a still quite startup.

BE11:23am

But that's all getting ahead of ourselves. Let me grab something to talk us through the numbers.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

UBS. Michael Briest.

BE11:23am

Sophos reported 18% c/c billings growth to $164m (cons. $161m), led by Enduser growing "in excess of 20%". While this suggests lower growth in Network we expected tough comparatives here (Q3 16: +32%) to create a headwind. This puts billings year-to-date up c16%, in-line with guidance of "mid-teens" growth, while a Q3 17 cash EBITDA margin of 30.0% (Q3 16: 24.6%) means the ytd cash EBITDA margin is up 160bp y/y to 22.6%, likely ahead of the target for "modest" margin expansion in the year; consensus is looking for 80bp in the full year. Unlevered FCF of $18m puts the ytd figure at $80m (+136%) and mgt raises its guidance for unlevered FCF to "more than double" for the year after $46m in 2016. Cons. is at $97m we note.

BE11:24am

Intercept X, based on SurfRight's anti-ransomware technology was launched in September 2016. Despite only being available through Sophos Central in the cloud, it gained 3,300 customers in the quarter, helping drive Enduser's strength. Sophos enduser solutions have moved up sharply in industry-analyst rankings as it has innovated organically and inorganically, and today it announces the purchase of Invincea's signature-less next-generation machine learning and behavioural monitoring anti-malware technologies. While a total cost of up to $120m (including $20m in earn-outs) may seem high against 2016 billings of $13m (some of which may be retained by Invincea Labs which is not being bought), SurfRight cost 8x billings and Palo Alto's 2014 $200m acquisition of Cyvera was at 20x, we believe. Innovation is not cheap.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Invincea is not expected to add anything to FY 18 cash EBITDA and we believe it will likely take 9-12m to integrate its technology, as with SurfRight. A key question for investors is whether this supports higher growth targets medium-term or merely sustains the existing targets. With 220,000 customers and a fragmented external market still addressable, we think this should improve Sophos' ability to execute.

PM11:25am

So all quite positive

PM11:26am

Hence SOPH:LSE

11:25 am
Sophos Group PLC (SOPH:LSE): Last: 289.00, up 19.3 (+7.16%), High: 291.60, Low: 273.10, Volume: 468.97k
BE11:26am

And Numis. David Toms.

BE11:26am

Sophos has produced a strong Q3 with 18% LFL billings growth (NSe 16%) and cash EBITDA c. 10% ahead of our $45m expectation. We make no changes to forecasts although the separate announcement of the acquisition of Invincea for $100m cash will likely be helpful to billings, neutral to Cash EBITDA/FCF and slightly dilutive to valuation. Within the mix, Endpoint is very strong (greater than +20% y/y) and Network weak (c.12% we estimate), and on a TTM basis we think Endpoint is c.20% and Network c.16%, a surprisingly inversion of the kind of growth profile expected at the time of IPO. We think this highlights the opportunity and risk - the company is successfully innovating and acquiring to deliver new products to new and existing customers, thus outperforming its market and generating strong cash. However, medium term visibility of product cycle changes is limited and Sophos has been relatively dependent on acquisition to meet these. In our view, the fundamental merits of the financial model remain under-appreciated by the market and we see ongoing opportunity for rerating as the company continues to deliver.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

And a clarification: it was David and Will who explained to me with a schoolteacher's patience how Sophos's numbers work. That's the value of sellside in action right there.

undefined
PM11:28am

Thumbs up

11:28 am
PM11:28am

BBA aviation mentioned on the right, but we're a bit clueless on this

BBA Aviation PLC (BBA:LSE): Last: 300.00, up 14.9 (+5.23%), High: 300.30, Low: 283.90, Volume: 2.05m
BE11:28am

I think there's a Caz note knocking around .....

11:28 am
BE11:29am

.... Which I've not read yet, but am about to.

PM11:29am

Ah, that's it -- sellside moving a stock

BE11:29am

Yep, they're positive. So that'll do as a reason and/or excuse.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

We provide data that indicates y/y US biz jet fuel burn growth of c.8%, vs FAA flight volume growth of 1% over the same period. We believe this divergence is due to a long-term trend towards larger planes, which combined with rapidly improving corporate confidence provides a strongly positive market backdrop. We believe consensus Flight Support organic growth estimates could be 5% too low for FY17e onwards, which would lead to c.15% FY18e upgrades. We remain OW, 347p TP (from 300p). We increase our forecasts by c.5%, bringing us slightly ahead of consensus.

BE11:30am

Course, most fund managers could've found fuel burn data themselves, independently of their broker.

PM11:30am

hehehehe

11:30 am
BE11:30am

We estimate that at least 60% of BBA Aviation’s earnings
are attributable to refueling business jets in the US. TTM US biz jet fuel burn has grown by c.8% y/y, compared to FAA flight volume growth of 1%. We think this helps to explain Signature’s strong L4Ls in Q2 and Q3 FY16 of c.5%, and makes us increasingly optimistic on the company outlook. We note that the rate of fuel burn growth continues to increase, and is up 8.6% y/y in Q4, vs 6.2% in Q3 FY16e.

BE11:31am

Want a chart?

PM11:31am

sure

11:32 am
BE11:32am

undefined
PM11:32am

Bit of housebuilders?

11:32 am
PM11:32am

Redrow numbers out

PM11:33am

http://www.investe...1702080700072774W/

PM11:33am

taylor Wimpey at the top of the Footsie board...

11:33 am
PM11:33am

Redrow numbers looked pretty outstanding i thought

BE11:33am

They're decent, certainly.

BE11:34am

We can also go on some more about the white paper, though it's been given comprehensive coverage in all papers this morning.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Back to Redrow though. Material upgrade to forward guidance.

BE11:35am

Guiding for 2019 revenue of £1.9bn, vs consensus of £1.685bn.

BE11:35am

That's £1.9bn on an EBIT margin of 19.5%.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

So: £370m. Consensus was less than £300m.

PM11:35am

Sheesh

Redrow PLC (RDW:LSE): Last: 471.30, up 18.8 (+4.15%), High: 475.00, Low: 463.00, Volume: 980.75k
11:35 am
BE11:36am

EPS guide is 77p though even that looks a bit lowballed.

BE11:36am

Robin Hardy of Shore incoming. He's a buyer.

BE11:36am

So, we are looking at a 10% increase in FY2019F numbers with lower but stepping increases for FY2017 and FY2018: we would initially raise FY2017 by 6.5% to £290m PBT and FY2018 by 8% to £321m. Needless to say, trading has been strong but part of the step up in scale will have been due to the acquisition of private house builder Radleigh Homes in the last few days – this has added 1,300 plots of land with potential for 1,200 more from strategic holdings. All of the metrics were positive in H1 with one of the largest increases in margins we have seen recently with a rise of 130bps. Otherwise, sales rates have risen more in line with the competition but the rise in the average selling price (+12%) has been greater (mix and location rather than underlying). The dividend has increased by materially more than EPS hinting at a faster drop in cover (we had forecast still 3.8x by FY2019) and if this drop to 3x, the yield on year 3 DPS could push above 5.5%

11:36 am
BE11:36am

As the FY2019 EPS is, essentially our valuation point for Redrow, a rise of 10% feeds directly through to our estimate of fair value. Our previously valuation was 475p so we step this up to 522p, making the shares under-priced by 16% in our view. We have had a BUY recommendation on the stock for a while and we stick with that both for absolute potential gain and also as part of our wider view that the midcap house builders offer much better value than the larger caps. So, Redrow remains an outright buy and a destination for intra-sector rotation. After a similar jump in guidance in 2014 the shares showed an immediate, strong bounce; the same is possible today.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets LIve

BE11:38am

Redrow has achieved strong first half results, with PBT up 35% to £140m, about 8% better than we expected. Management has said that the resilience of the housing market has continued into January and as a sign of confidence has raised the H1 dividend by 50% to 6p. Management has given new guidance for June 2019, aiming for 77p EPS, 11% cagr vs 2016, and about 17% ahead of consensus. Bellway (BUY, TP 2780p) is our preferred grower, but Redrow is trading at around 6x 2019 EPS guidance, but this will need a stronger housing market than we expect.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Redrow has published new medium term guidance for its June 2019 year, aiming to achieve £1.9bn of sales, an operating margin of 19.5% and EPS of 77p, which compares to consensus expectations of 66p. The revised guidance includes a contribution from Radleigh, a Midlands housebuilder acquired in February. Its guidance implies an EPS cagr of 11% pa between 2016 and 2019, and if the guidance is achieved, the shares are now on under 6x PER June 2019.

Our estimates are some way below this guidance as we are explicitly forecasting slowing house prices (-2.5%) in 2017 in response to a widely expected slowing of the UK economy. We admit though that with January still strong, it seems increasingly likely that the spring selling season will prove satisfactory for the builders.

Looking at the sector, we see most upside in Bellway (BUY, TP 2780p), which is our preferred grower. We have a HOLD rating on Redrow, but its shares may be very cheap if its 2019 guidance is achieved (but this needs a steadier housing market than we expect over the next two years).

BE11:38am

In terms of the sector ......

Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 177.80, up 5.7 (+3.31%), High: 178.00, Low: 172.30, Volume: 7.45m
11:38 am
Persimmon PLC (PSN:LSE): Last: 2,016, up 59 (+3.01%), High: 2,020, Low: 1,962, Volume: 426.76k
Bellway PLC (BWY:LSE): Last: 2,653, up 86 (+3.35%), High: 2,656, Low: 2,583, Volume: 220.98k
BE11:40am

And just for completeness -- one line on the white paper, via Caz.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Digging through the detail, we are not expecting the contents to have a material impact on housebuilding operations.

BE11:40am

Which I think is the market's reading too. All that noise and no effect whatsoever. Waste of bloody time.

undefined
11:41 am
BE11:41am

Speaking of Caz, there was a request earlier for their push of Sirius Minerals.

Sirius Minerals PLC (SXX:LSE): Last: 18.00, up 0.5 (+2.86%), High: 18.25, Low: 17.75, Volume: 16.34m
BE11:42am

40p target!

11:42 am
BE11:43am

Our positive view is underpinned by: (i) compelling valuation metrics which makes it the cheapest in our EMEA coverage; (ii) permitting risks have now dissipated; (iii) Stage 1 funding capitalises project spend until H1’19 (JPMe); (iv) attractive base case project economics, with downside risks mitigated but with optionality to materially improve; and (v) leverage to the fertiliser market which should drive a premium rating to mining peers over time.

PM11:43am

Blimey

BE11:44am

51 page note, this. I've not been through it in any kind of detail, so haven't challenged my uninformed cynicism about the idea of digging up a lot of Yorkshire.

11:44 am
PM11:44am

Yeah, where is it in Yorkshire

PM11:44am

North yorkshire somewhere

PM11:44am

11:44 am
PM11:45am

Near Whitby apparently

BE11:45am

That's the one. I've recommended readers have a virtual drive around the area via Google Maps, to try and imagine where the infrastructure goes.

BE11:45am

Caz's work is rather more detailed, though. Let me get the exec summary.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

(@Rudi: really? First I've heard of it.)

PM11:46am

(Don't be cruel Bryce)

BE11:46am

 Geological & geographical setting unlock competitive advantage – we believe there is a high likelihood that reserves will be extended which will underpin a mine life potentially greater than 100 years. Furthermore, the orebody is amenable to low-cost, bulk mining methods which we expect to drive steady-state EBITDA margins ~74%.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

 Project economics are supportive under JPM forecasts – JPM base case forecasts with production of 13Mtpa yields an IRR of 17% (real, 2017) with returns resilient even under more bearish assumptions. However, we believe there are further opportunities to refine capital operating metrics which could materially improve the investment case. For example, a "high volume high margin" scenario would increase the IRR to a very attractive ~32%

BE11:46am

 Equity valuations are attractive – We calculate a base case DCF of £0.97/sh.,& a range of £0.41-1.61/sh. using a multiples (EV/EBITDA) approach. Using the DCF, it would mean the current stock price is trading at less than 0.2x P/NPV, implying SXX is the cheapest within our coverage universe.

BE11:46am

 Financing risks have diminished – Following the Stage 1 financing package (announced Nov’16), we believe SXX is fully capitalised for project spend until H1’19. This has eased pressure on the immediacy to commit Stage 2 funding (fully debt funded, expected in 2018), although we still forecast that funding will be tight between 2023-‘25 as: (i) production ramps up, and (ii) the convertible bond is repaid.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

 Development has derisked materially – Shaft sinking and cavern boring for the conveyor system present a technically challenging development that is more acute given that the Project sits within the North York Moors National Park. However, all necessary approvals have been obtained to start construction (and for production up to 13Mtpa) and key components of the Project have been assessed by independent consultants which should mitigate development risk.

BE11:47am

 Leveraged to late-cycle commodities – SXX will mine and market polyhalite, which is a naturally occurring fertiliser that contains four macronutrients which are required for plant growth. As such, the long-term outlook for the company is tied to favourable underlying trends such as population growth, urbanisation and increasing wealth.

BE11:48am

The other 50 pages have some excellent graphs that I don't understand.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

BE11:48am

Anyway, that's that.

undefined
11:48 am
PM11:49am

So this Corbyn rumour

BE11:49am

Hmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm ..................

PM11:49am

It's down to this hack

11:49 am
PM11:49am

https://twitter.com/JenWilliamsMEN/status/829117403225260032

PM11:49am

From the Manchester Evening News

BE11:49am

Well, partly down to that hack.

11:49 am
PM11:50am

https://twitter.com/JenWilliamsMEN

PM11:50am

Go on

BE11:50am

Also down to MailOnline and some other places picking up her heavily caveated tweet and running it as a full story

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Which is something the Manchester Evening News didn't do.

PM11:50am

Well yes, that's true

PM11:51am

People should read her full twitter stream on it

11:51 am
BE11:51am

It's kinda unfair, publishing another hack's info and extracting worth from it (albeit negligible click worth) while still making her wear the risk.

BE11:52am

Very unfair, in fact. But that's an aside.

PM11:52am

This woman supposedly being lined up as successor...

11:52 am
PM11:52am

She's only been in the Commons for less than 2 years

PM11:53am

https://en.wikiped...ebecca_Long-Bailey

PM11:53am

But then I guess Labour needs fresh blood

11:53 am
undefined
PM11:53am

Was trying to catch up with this Greek stuff

PM11:53am

You know -- fresh spat between the Eurozone and the IMF

11:53 am
PM11:53am

etc etc

BE11:53am

There's still Greece stuff? Cripes.

PM11:54am

But you read it and it's like exactly the same story, repeated over and over

11:54 am
PM11:54am

Surreal

PM11:54am

Have some Citi

PM11:54am

IMF-Eurozone dispute behind bailout impasse – Creditors’ disagreement on Greece’s bailout targets and the need for more debt relief is the main stumbling block to the second review, causing significant market concerns. On one side, the IMF calls for more realistic medium-term growth/fiscal targets (1% growth and 1.5% of GDP primary surplus) than currently (of 1.5% and 3.5%, respectively) and more debt relief to allow Greece to eventually return to market funding. On the other, the EA seem very much against new concessions, beyond the Dec-16 minor debt relief due to (a) unpopularity of support for Greece in key creditors facing near-term national elections (Germany and Netherlands) and (b) Athens’ still-low level of bailout ownership and low mutual trust.

11:54 am
PM11:54am

Dispute is nothing new – IMF participation in the third programme was one of the key hurdles at its inception (Aug 2015) and at the time of the first review completion (May 2016). In both cases, the impasse ended with the IMF staying on board with just a supervisory role (i.e., no new money committed) and with a vague pledge to reassess this position at a later stage. EA creditors (in particular, Germany) accepted this as enough to continue financing Greece. We reckon this time is not going to be much different. The worst case is if the IMF pulls out completely, perhaps on the back of the apparent anti-EU stance of the new US administration. If so, EU creditors (and Germany in particular) will face the choices of (i) accepting an IMF-free, ESM-only, bailout programme and continue financing Greece, (ii) submitting option (i) to (quite uncertain) parliamentary votes, or (iii) letting Greece default. Note the German Bundestag is probably not legally obliged to pass a new bailout if the IMF pulls out, contrary to German FinMin’s position, although it may still want to hold a vote. We believe option (iii) remains by and large the least likely in such an important political year for Europe.

PM11:55am

Here's an iron fact...

PM11:55am

Negotiations may still drag on for weeks/months

11:55 am
PM11:55am

Risks of snap election in Greece may still rise, although we still believe they remain unlikely. This suggests a deal may not be reached soon. Yet, the current brinkmanship is unlikely, in our view, to lead to a new Greek default and concrete risks of Grexit.

PM11:55am

So that's that. No change.

undefined
11:55 am
BE11:56am

Results wise, not sure there's much that caught the attention.

BE11:56am

Request on the right for Smurfit, but I really do think we've done enough on containerboard pricing already this year.

BE11:57am

I've made a note in my diary to check the kraftliner European pricing index every Thursday. That's how bad it's got.

11:57 am
Smurfit Kappa Group PLC (SKG:LSE): Last: 2,194, up 50 (+2.33%), High: 2,200, Low: 2,149, Volume: 268.21k
BE11:58am

Otherwise, there's Dunelm.

BE11:58am

"Transitional year"

11:59 am
BE11:59am

The old football joke is that transitional years are usually from bad to worse, but let's hope that's not the case for the premier discount towel and tablecloth retailer.

Dunelm Group PLC (DNLM:LSE): Last: 626.50, down 58 (-8.47%), High: 671.50, Low: 610.00, Volume: 702.12k
BE11:59am

Canaccord can summarise.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

As expected, Dunelm has reported a decline in profits at its core homewares division, along with a maiden trading loss from WS Group, which was acquired in November.
The core Dunelm division reported a 9.9% decline in operating profit to £68.1m from £75.6m last year, with the operating margin down 182bps to 15.1%. With the gross margin nudging forward by around 10bps, the operational deleverage arises from negative LFL sales growth (down 1.6%, or down 0.7% on an adjusted basis) and 6.7% growth in operating costs. The latter include £3m of incremental costs associated with supplier consolidation and teething problems in the new warehouse, with a total of £4m expected for the full year. Management has indicated its expectation of flat gross margin in H2, with some FX-driven price increases coming through (averaging around 5%).
The recently acquired WS Group has reported an operating loss of £1.8m, with management now pointing to the upper end of its range guidance for the full year operating loss of £5m - £10m. This shift in guidance reflects needing longer to re-establish supplier continuity within WS, which has also had a drag effect on turnover. Management is still anticipating WS to break even in FY18 before moving into profitability in FY19. In addition, Dunelm reported £9.3m of exceptional costs associated with the WS acquisition.
On the dividend front, Dunelm has raised the interim dividend by 8.3% to 6.5p. Daily average net debt in the period was £77.6m, as reported in the Q2 trading update, with net debt of £103.8m at the period end, equating to 0.71x historical EBITDA, excluding exceptionals.

BE12:00pm

It is difficult to gauge these results against market expectations, in our view, but both core Dunelm and WS performed better than we had expected. We had forecast group H1 PBT, including WS losses, of £62.5m, compared with the £65.2m delivered. Operational deleverage impacts were offset by around £2.5m of cost savings in the period. These came from a number of sources, with management indicating a similar level in H2. This underlines management's focus on a lean cost model, notwithstanding the ongoing investment in store openings, IT and infrastructure. Subject to any new news emerging in the presentation meeting, we do not anticipate any changes to our PBT forecasts at this stage.

BE12:00pm

The shares, on last night's close, are trading on a cal 17 PER of 14.0x, with a corresponding EV/EBITDA multiple of 9.2x and ordinary dividend yield of 3.7%. This represents a modest premium of under 5% to the wider sector.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Hm.

undefined
BE12:01pm

And on Aberdeen, which @Chopper asked about .....

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

RBC pushing.

BE12:01pm

Or rather, it's a "close your shorts" call. Peter Lenardos of course.

BE12:02pm

We adjust EPS by +0.4%+0.1%-2.8% in FY17E/FY18E/FY19E as lower net flow assumptions are offset by anticipated improved investment performance and FX movements, resulting in our price target moving 2% lower to 285p. We value Aberdeen in line with longer-term sector averages (13x forward EPS and 9x forward EBITDA). Even if we valued Aberdeen at a one-turn discount to both our current valuation methodology and longer-term sector averages, we would obtain a valuation of 260p which is above the current share price.

The event risk is too high to be short the shares. Aberdeen
could be attractive for suitors looking to expand and/or to build an emerging markets equity franchise, especially given Aberdeen’s share price correction, valuation and the weak sterling. Further, accretive, transformational M&A is also possible. Aberdeen’s CEO has repeatedly said that he would like a deal “similar to Janus Henderson,” and that he is keen to expand in the US. We believe that Aberdeen continues to seek M&A opportunities; indeed, the CEO has even publicly indicated that Aberdeen is “open to a deal.”
